abstract.para: GRUB 2 enables booting from btrfs snapshots and thus allows you to use any older functional snapshot in case the new snapshot does not work correctly.

topic.para: When booting a snapshot, the parts of the file system included in the snapshot are mounted read-only; all other file systems and parts that are excluded from snapshots are mounted read-write and can be modified.

tip.title: Rolling back to a specific installation state
tip.para: An initial bootable snapshot is created at the end of the initial system installation. You can go back to that state at any time by booting this snapshot. The snapshot can be identified by the description after installation.

topic.para: There are two methods to perform a system rollback.

listitem.para: From a running system, you can set the default snapshot, see more in .

topic.para: The following procedure is used in case the current snapshot is broken and you cannot boot into it.

step.para: Reboot your system and select Start bootloader from a read-only snapshot.
Choose a snapshot to boot. The snapshots are sorted according to the date of creation, with the latest one at the top.
Log in to your system and check whether everything works as expected. The data written to directories excluded from the snapshots will stay untouched.
